ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Transport] This protocol [MS-ASPROV] consists of a series of XML elements contained in request or response messages that is associated with the Provision command between a client and server.
[In Transport] The encoded XML block containing the command and parameter elements is transmitted in[ either] the request body of a request[, or in the response body of a response].
[In Transport] The encoded XML block containing the command and parameter elements is transmitted[ in either the request body of a request, or] in the response body of a response.
[In Transport] All Provision command messages are encoded as Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) Binary XML (WBXML), as specified in [MS-ASWBXML].
[In Message Syntax] The XML schema for the Provision namespace is described in section 6.
[In Namespaces] This specification [MS-ASPROV] defines and references various XML namespaces using the mechanisms specified in [XMLNS].

[In Namespaces] Although this specification [MS-ASPROV] associates a specific XML namespace prefix for each XML namespace that is used, the choice of any particular XML namespace prefix is implementation-specific and not significant for interoperability.
[In Namespaces] Prefix "None" is used for namespace URI "Provision".
[In Namespaces] Prefix "folderhierarchy" is used for namespace URI "FolderHierarchy" and reference [MS-ASCMD] sections 2.2.1.3, 2.2.1.4, 2.2.1.5, 2.2.1.6, 2.2.1.8.
[In Namespaces] Prefix "settings" is used for namespace URI "Settings" and reference [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.18.
[In Namespaces] Prefix "xs" is used for namespace URI "http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema and reference [XMLSCHEMA1].

[In Elements] The following table summarizes the set of common XML schema element [AccountOnlyRemoteWipe, AllowBluetooth, AllowBrowser, AllowCamera, AllowConsumerEmail, AllowDesktopSync, AllowHTMLEmail, AllowInternetSharing, AllowIrDA, AllowPOPIMAPEmail, AllowRemoteDesktop, AllowSimpleDevicePassword, AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation, AllowSMIMESoftCerts, AllowStorageCard, AllowTextMessaging, AllowUnsignedApplications, AllowUnsignedInstallationPackages, AllowWiFi, AlphanumericDevicePasswordRequired, ApplicationName, ApprovedApplicationList, AttachmentsEnabled, Data, DevicePasswordEnabled, DevicePasswordExpiration, DevicePasswordHistory, EASProvisionDoc, Hash, MaxAttachmentSize, MaxCalendarAgeFilter, MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts, MaxEmailAgeFilter, MaxEmailBodyTruncationSize, MaxEmailHTMLBodyTruncationSize, MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock, MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters, MinDevicePasswordLength, PasswordRecoveryEnabled, Policies, Policy, PolicyKey, PolicyType, Provision, RemoteWipe, RequireDeviceEncryption, RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages, RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm, RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming, RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm, RequireSignedSMIMEMessages, RequireStorageCardEncryption, settings:DeviceInformation, Status, UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] definitions that are defined or used by this specification [MS-ASPROV].
[In Elements] XML schema elements that are specific to a particular command are described in the context of its [XML schema element's] associated command.

[In Elements] [Element] AccountOnlyRemoteWipe (section 2.2.2.1) [is described as] Specifies either an account only remote wipe directive from the server or a client's confirmation of an account only remote wipe directive.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowBluetooth (section 2.2.2.2) [is described as] Whether Bluetooth and hands-free profiles are allowed on the device.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowBrowser (section 2.2.2.3) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of a web browser.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowCamera (section 2.2.2.4) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of the built-in camera.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowConsumerEmail (section 2.2.2.5) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of personal email.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowDesktopSync (section 2.2.2.6) [is described as] Whether the device allows synchronization with Desktop ActiveSync.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowHTMLEmail (section 2.2.2.7) [is described as] Whether the device uses HTML-formatted email.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowInternetSharing (section 2.2.2.8) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of Internet Sharing.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowIrDA (section 2.2.2.9) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of IrDA (infrared) connections.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowPOPIMAPEmail (section 2.2.2.10) [is described as] Whether the device allows access to POP/IMAP email.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowRemoteDesktop (section 2.2.2.11) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of Remote Desktop.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowSimpleDevicePassword (section 2.2.2.12) [is described as] Whether the device allows simple passwords.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation (section 2.2.2.13) [is described as] Whether the device can negotiate the encryption algorithm to be used for signing.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowSMIMESoftCerts (section 2.2.2.14) [is described as] Whether the device uses soft certificates to sign outgoing messages.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowStorageCard (section 2.2.2.15) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of the storage card.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowTextMessaging (section 2.2.2.16) [is described as] Whether the device allows Short Message Service (SMS)/text messaging.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowUnsignedApplications (section 2.2.2.17) [is described as] Whether the device allows unsigned applications to execute.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowUnsignedInstallationPackages (section 2.2.2.18) [is described as] Whether the device allows unsigned cabinet (.cab) files to be installed.
[In Elements] [Element] AllowWiFi (section 2.2.2.19) [is described as] Whether the device allows the use of Wi-Fi connections.
[In Elements] [Element] AlphanumericDevicePasswordRequired (section 2.2.2.20) [is described as] Indicates whether a client device requires an alphanumeric password.
[In Elements] [Element] ApplicationName (section 2.2.2.21) [is described as] The name of an in-ROM application (.exe file) that is not approved for execution.
[In Elements] [Element] ApprovedApplicationList (section 2.2.2.22) [is described as] A list of in-RAM applications that are approved for execution.
[In Elements] [Element] AttachmentsEnabled (section 2.2.2.23) [is described as] Indicates whether email attachments are enabled.
[In Elements] [Element] Data (section 2.2.2.24) [is described as] The settings for a policy.
[In Elements] [Element] DevicePasswordEnabled (section 2.2.2.25) [is described as] Indicates whether a client device requires a password.
[In Elements] [Element] DevicePasswordExpiration (section 2.2.2.26) [is described as] Whether the password expires after the specified number of days, as determined by the policy.
[In Elements] [Element] DevicePasswordHistory (section 2.2.2.27) [is described as] The minimum number of previously used passwords the client device stores to prevent reuse.
[In Elements] [Element] EASProvisionDoc (section 2.2.2.28) [is described as] The collection of security settings for device provisioning.
[In Elements] [Element] Hash (section 2.2.2.29) [is described as] The SHA-1 hash of an in-memory application that is approved for execution.
[In Elements] [Element] MaxAttachmentSize (section 2.2.2.30) [is described as] The maximum attachment size, as determined by the security policy.
[In Elements] [Element] MaxCalendarAgeFilter (section 2.2.2.31) [is described as] The maximum number of calendar days that can be synchronized.
[In Elements] [Element] MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts (section 2.2.2.32) [is described as] The number of password failures that are permitted before the device is wiped.
[In Elements] [Element] MaxEmailAgeFilter (section 2.2.2.33) [is described as] The email age limit for synchronization.
[In Elements] [Element] MaxEmailBodyTruncationSize (section 2.2.2.34) [is described as] The truncation size for plain textâ€“formatted email messages.
[In Elements] [Element] MaxEmailHTMLBodyTruncationSize (section 2.2.2.35) [is described as] The truncation size for HTML-formatted email messages.
[In Elements] [Element] MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock (section 2.2.2.36) [is described as] The number of seconds of inactivity before the device locks itself.
[In Elements] [Element] MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters (section 2.2.2.37) [is described as] The minimum number of complex characters (numbers and symbols) contained within the password.
[In Elements] [Element] MinDevicePasswordLength (section 2.2.2.38) [is described as] The minimum device password length that the user can enter.
[In Elements] [Element] PasswordRecoveryEnabled (section 2.2.2.39) [is described as] Indicates whether to enable a recovery password to be sent to the server by using the Settings command.
[In Elements] [Element] Policies (section 2.2.2.40) [is described as] A collection of security policies.
[In Elements] [Element] Policy (section 2.2.2.41) [is described as] A policy.
[In Elements] [Element] PolicyKey (section 2.2.2.42) [is described as] Used by the server to mark the state of policy settings on the client.
[In Elements] [Element] PolicyType (section 2.2.2.43) [is described as] Specifies the format in which the policy settings are to be provided.
[In Elements] [Element] Provision (section 2.2.2.44) [is described as] The capabilities and permissions for the device.
[In Elements] [Element] RemoteWipe (section 2.2.2.45) [is described as] Specifies either a remote wipe directive from the server or a client's confirmation of a remote wipe directive.
[In Elements] [Element] RequireDeviceEncryption (section 2.2.2.46) [is described as] Whether the device uses encryption.
[In Elements] [Element] RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages (section 2.2.2.47) [is described as] Whether the device is required to send encrypted messages.
[In Elements] [Element] RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm (section 2.2.2.48) [is described as] The algorithm to be used when encrypting a message.
[In Elements] [Element] RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming (section 2.2.2.49) [is described as] Whether the device requires manual synchronization when the device is roaming.
[In Elements] [Element] RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm (section 2.2.2.50) [is described as] The algorithm to be used when signing a message.
[In Elements] [Element] RequireSignedSMIMEMessages (section 2.2.2.51) [is described as] Whether the device is required to send signed S/MIME messages.
[In Elements] [Element] RequireStorageCardEncryption (section 2.2.2.52) [is described as] Indicates whether the device has to encrypt content that is stored on the storage card.
[In Elements] [Element] settings:DeviceInformation (section 2.2.2.53) [is described as] Specifies the settings for the device in an initial Provisioning request.
[In Elements] [Element] Status (section 2.2.2.54) [is described as] Indicates success or failure of specific parts of a command.
[In Elements] [Element] UnapprovedInROMApplicationList (section 2.2.2.55) [is described as] A list of in-ROM applications that are not approved for execution.
[In AccountOnlyRemoteWipe] The AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element is an optional container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element.

[In AccountOnlyRemoteWipe] [The AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element] specifies either an account only remote wipe directive from the server or a client's confirmation of a server's account only remote wipe directive.
[In AccountOnlyRemoteWipe] A server response MUST NOT include any child elements in the AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element.
[In AccountOnlyRemoteWipe] The AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element is sent in a command request only in response to an account only remote wipe directive from the server.
[In AccountOnlyRemoteWipe] The AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element has the following child element in a command request: Status (section 2.2.2.54.3): One element of this type is required.
[In AccountOnlyRemoteWipe] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AccountOnlyRemoteWipe] element.
[In AllowBluetooth] The AllowBluetooth element is an optional child element of type unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowBluetooth] [The AllowBluetooth element] specifies the use of Bluetooth on the device.
[In AllowBluetooth] The AllowBluetooth element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowBluetooth] Valid values [0,1,2] for AllowBluetooth are listed in the following table.
[In AllowBluetooth] Value 0 means Disable Bluetooth.
[In AllowBluetooth] Value 1 means Disable Bluetooth, but allow the configuration of hands-free profiles.
[In AllowBluetooth] Value 2 means Allow Bluetooth.
[In AllowBluetooth] This element [AllowBluetooth] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support Bluetooth.
[In AllowBluetooth] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowBluetooth] element.
[In AllowBluetooth] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowBluetooth] element.
[In AllowBluetooth] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowBluetooth] element.
[In AllowBluetooth] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowBluetooth] element.
[In AllowBluetooth] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowBluetooth] element.
[In AllowBrowser] The AllowBrowser element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowBrowser] [The AllowBrowser element] specifies whether the device allows the use of a web browser.
[In AllowBrowser] The AllowBrowser element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowBrowser] Valid values [0,1] for AllowBrowser are listed in the following table.
[In AllowBrowser] Value 0 means Do not allow the use of a web browser.
[In AllowBrowser] Value 1 means Allow the use of a web browser.
[In AllowBrowser] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowBrowser] element.
[In AllowBrowser] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowBrowser] element.
[In AllowBrowser] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowBrowser] element.
[In AllowBrowser] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowBrowser] element.
[In AllowBrowser] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowBrowser] element.
[In AllowCamera] The AllowCamera element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowCamera] [The AllowCamera element] specifies whether the device allows the use of the built-in camera.
[In AllowCamera] The AllowCamera element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowCamera] Valid values [0,1] for AllowCamera are listed in the following table.
[In AllowCamera] Value 0 means Use of the camera is not allowed.
[In AllowCamera] Value 1 means Use of the camera is allowed.
[In AllowCamera] This element [AllowCamera] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not have a camera and no camera can be attached to the device.
[In AllowCamera] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowCamera] element.
[In AllowCamera] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowCamera] element.
[In AllowCamera] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowCamera] element.
[In AllowCamera] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowCamera] element.
[In AllowCamera] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowCamera] element.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] The AllowConsumerEmail element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowConsumerEmail] [The AllowConsumerEmail element] specifies whether the device allows the user to configure a personal email account.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] The AllowConsumerEmail element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Valid values [0,1] for AllowConsumerEmail are listed in the following table.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Value 0 means Do not allow the user to configure a personal email account.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Value 1 menas Allow the user to configure a personal email account.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowConsumerEmail] element.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowConsumerEmail] element.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowConsumerEmail] element.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowConsumerEmail] element.
[In AllowConsumerEmail] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowConsumerEmail] element.
[In AllowDesktopSync] The AllowDesktopSync element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowDesktopSync] [The AllowDesktopSync element] specifies whether the device allows synchronization with Desktop ActiveSync.
[In AllowDesktopSync] The AllowDesktopSync element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Valid values [0,1] for AllowDesktopSync are listed in the following table.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Value 0 means Do not allow Desktop ActiveSync.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Value 1 means Allow Desktop ActiveSync.
[In AllowDesktopSync] This element [AllowDesktopSync] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support connecting to a personal computer.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowDesktopSync] element.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowDesktopSync] element.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowDesktopSync] element.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowDesktopSync] element.
[In AllowDesktopSync] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowDesktopSync] element.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] The AllowHTMLEmail element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowHTMLEmail] [The AllowHTMLEmail element] specifies whether the client uses HTML-formatted email.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] The AllowHTMLEmail element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Valid values [0,1] for AllowHTMLEmail are listed in the following table.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Value 0 means HTML-formatted email is not allowed.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Value 1 means HTML-formatted email is allowed.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowHTMLEmail] element.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowHTMLEmail] element.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowHTMLEmail] element.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowHTMLEmail] element.
[In AllowHTMLEmail] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowHTMLEmail] element.
[In AllowInternetSharing] The AllowInternetSharing element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowInternetSharing] [The AllowInternetSharing element] specifies whether the device allows the use of Internet Sharing.
[In AllowInternetSharing] The AllowInternetSharing element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Valid values [0,1] for AllowInternetSharing are listed in the following table.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Value 0 means Do not allow the use of Internet Sharing.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Value 1 means Allow the use of Internet Sharing.
[In AllowInternetSharing] This element [AllowInternetSharing] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support sharing its internet connection with other devices.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowInternetSharing] element.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowInternetSharing] element.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowInternetSharing] element.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowInternetSharing] element.
[In AllowInternetSharing] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowInternetSharing] element.
[In AllowIrDA] The AllowIrDA element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowIrDA] [The AllowIrDA element] specifies whether the device allows the use of IrDA (infrared) connections.
[In AllowIrDA] The AllowIrDA element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowIrDA] Valid values [0,1] for AllowIrDA are listed in the following table.
[In AllowIrDA] Value 0 means Disable IrDA.
[In AllowIrDA] Value 1 means Allow IrDA.
[In AllowIrDA] This element [AllowIrDA] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not have the capability of transmitting or receiving infrared signals.
[In AllowIrDA] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowIrDA] element.
[In AllowIrDA] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowIrDA] element.
[In AllowIrDA] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowIrDA] element.
[In AllowIrDA] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowIrDA] element.
[In AllowIrDA] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowIrDA] element.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] The AllowPOPIMAPEmail element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] [The AllowPOPIMAPEmail element] specifies whether the device allows access to POP or IMAP email.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] The AllowPOPIMAPEmail element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Valid values [0,1] for AllowPOPIMAPEmail are listed in the following table.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Value 0 means POP or IMAP email access is not allowed.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Value 1 means POP or IMAP email access is allowed.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowPOPIMAPEmail] element.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowPOPIMAPEmail] element.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowPOPIMAPEmail] element.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowPOPIMAPEmail] element.
[In AllowPOPIMAPEmail] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowPOPIMAPEmail] element.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] The AllowRemoteDesktop element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] [The AllowRemoteDesktop element] specifies whether the device allows the use of Remote Desktop.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] The AllowRemoteDesktop element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Valid values [0,1] for AllowRemoteDesktop are listed in the following table.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Value 0 means Do not allow the use of Remote Desktop.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Value 1 means Allow the use of Remote Desktop.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] This element [AllowRemoteDesktop] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support connecting remotely to a personal computer.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowRemoteDesktop] element.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowRemoteDesktop] element.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowRemoteDesktop] element.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowRemoteDesktop] element.
[In AllowRemoteDesktop] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowRemoteDesktop] element.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] The AllowSimpleDevicePassword element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] [The AllowSimpleDevicePassword element] specifies whether the client allows simple passwords.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] A simple password is one consisting only of repeated ("2222") or sequential ("abcd") characters.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] The AllowSimpleDevicePassword element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Valid values [0,1] for AllowSimpleDevicePassword are listed in the following table.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Value 0 means Simple passwords are not allowed.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Value 1 means Simple passwords are allowed.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] If AllowSimpleDevicePassword is not included in a response, a client SHOULD treat this value as 1.

[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] If the AllowSimpleDevicePassword element is included in a response, and the value of the DevicePasswordEnabled element (section 2.2.2.25) is set to FALSE (0), the client SHOULD ignore this element.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowSimpleDevicePassword] element.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowSimpleDevicePassword] element.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowSimpleDevicePassword] element.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowSimpleDevicePassword] element.
[In AllowSimpleDevicePassword] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowSimpleDevicePassword] element.

[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] The AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotation element is an optional child element of type integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] [The AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotation element] controls negotiation of the encryption algorithm.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] The AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotation element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Valid values [0,1,2] for AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotation are listed in the following table.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Value 0 means Do not negotiate.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Value 1 means Negotiate a strong algorithm.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Value 2 means Negotiate any algorithm.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] element.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] element.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] element.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] element.
[In AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowSMIMEEncryptionAlgorithmNegotiation] element.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] The AllowSMIMESoftCerts element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] [The AllowSMIMESoftCerts element] specifies whether the client can use soft certificates to sign outgoing messages.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] The AllowSMIMESoftCerts element cannot have child elements.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Valid values [0,1] for AllowSMIMESoftCerts are listed in the following table.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Value 0 means Soft certificates are not allowed.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Value 1 means Soft certificates are allowed.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowSMIMESoftCerts] element.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowSMIMESoftCerts] element.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowSMIMESoftCerts] element.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowSMIMESoftCerts] element.
[In AllowSMIMESoftCerts] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowSMIMESoftCerts] element.
[In AllowStorageCard] The AllowStorageCard element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowStorageCard] [The AllowStorageCard element] specifies whether the device allows use of the storage card.

[In AllowStorageCard] Value 1 means SD card use is allowed.
[In AllowStorageCard] This element [AllowStorageCard] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support storing data on removable storage.
[In AllowStorageCard] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [AllowStorageCard] element.
[In AllowStorageCard] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [AllowStorageCard] element.
[In AllowStorageCard] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowStorageCard] element.
[In AllowStorageCard] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowStorageCard] element.
[In AllowStorageCard] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowStorageCard] element.

[In AllowTextMessaging] Value 1 means SMS or text messaging is allowed.
[In AllowTextMessaging] This element [AllowTextMessaging] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support SMS or text messaging.

[In AllowTextMessaging] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [AllowTextMessaging] element.
[In AllowTextMessaging] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [AllowTextMessaging] element.
[In AllowTextMessaging] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [AllowTextMessaging] element.
[In AllowUnsignedApplications] The AllowUnsignedApplications element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In AllowUnsignedApplications] [The AllowUnsignedApplications element] specifies whether the device allows unsigned applications to execute.

[In AllowUnsignedApplications] Valid values [0,1] for AllowUnsignedApplications are listed in the following table.

[In MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts] The MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts element is an optional child element of type unsignedByteOrEmpty (section 2.2.3.2) of the EASProvisionDoc element, as specified in section 2.2.2.28.
[In MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts] [The MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts element] specifies the maximum number of failed password logon attempts that are permitted.
[In MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts] The client SHOULD perform a local wipe or enter a timed lock out mode if the maximum number of failed password logon attempts is reached.
[In MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts] The MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts element cannot have child elements.

[In MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts] If the MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts element is included in a response, and the value of the DevicePasswordEnabled element (section 2.2.2.25) is set to FALSE (0), the client ignores this element.

[In MaxEmailBodyTruncationSize] The MaxEmailBodyTruncationSize element is an optional child element of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In MaxEmailBodyTruncationSize] [The MaxEmailBodyTruncationSize element] specifies the truncation size for plain textâ€“formatted email.

[In MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock] The MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock element is an optional child element of type unsignedIntOrEmpty (section 2.2.3.3) of the EASProvisionDoc element, as specified in section 2.2.2.28.
[In MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock] [The MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock element] specifies the maximum number of seconds of inactivity before the device locks itself.
[In MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock] The MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock element cannot have child elements.
[In MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock] If this [MaxInactivityTimeDeviceLock] value is greater than or equal to 9999, the client interprets it as unlimited.
