[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] The MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters element is an optional child element of type unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] [The MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters element] specifies the required level of complexity of the client password.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] The MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters element cannot have child elements.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] Valid values for MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters are 1 to 4.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] The value specifies the number of character groups that are required to be present in the password.

[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] The character [MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] groups are defined as: Lower case alphabetical characters Upper case alphabetical characters Numbers Non-alphanumeric characters

[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] For example, if the value of MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters is 2, a password with both upper case and lower case alphabetical characters would be sufficient, as would a password with lower case alphabetical characters and numbers.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters] element.

[In MinDevicePasswordLength] The MinDevicePasswordLength element is an optional child element of type unsignedByteOrEmpty (section 2.2.3.2) of the EASProvisionDoc element, as specified in section 2.2.2.28.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] [The MinDevicePasswordLength element] specifies the minimum client password length.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] The MinDevicePasswordLength element cannot have child elements.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] The MinDevicePasswordLength can be empty or have a value no less than 1 and no greater than 16.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] If the element [MinDevicePasswordLength] is empty or the value of this element [MinDevicePasswordLength] is 1, there is no minimum length for the device password.

[In MinDevicePasswordLength] If the MinDevicePasswordLength element is included in a response, and the value of the DevicePasswordEnabled element (section 2.2.2.25) is FALSE (0), the client SHOULD ignore this element.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [MinDevicePasswordLength] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [MinDevicePasswordLength] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [MinDevicePasswordLength] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [MinDevicePasswordLength] element.
[In MinDevicePasswordLength] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [MinDevicePasswordLength] element.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] The PasswordRecoveryEnabled element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] [The PasswordRecoveryEnabled element] specifies whether the server supports storage of a recovery password to be sent by the client using the Settings command.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] The PasswordRecoveryEnabled element cannot have child elements.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Valid values [0,1] for PasswordRecoveryEnabled are listed in the following table.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Value 0 means Password recovery is not enabled on the server.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Value 1 means Password recovery is enabled on the server.

[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] A recovery password is a special password created by the client that gives the administrator or user the ability to log on to the device one time, after which the user is required to create a new password.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] The client then creates a new recovery password.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] If the PasswordRecoveryEnabled element is set to 1 (TRUE), the server supports storage of a recovery password sent by the device.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] If the element [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] is set to 0 (FALSE), the device SHOULD NOT send a recovery password, because the server does not support storage of the password.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] If PasswordRecoveryEnabled is not included in a response, a client SHOULD treat this [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] value as 0.

[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] If the PasswordRecoveryEnabled element is included in a response, and the value of the DevicePasswordEnabled element (section 2.2.2.25) is FALSE (0), the client SHOULD ignore this element [PasswordRecoveryEnabled].
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] This element [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support recovery passwords.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] element.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] element.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] element.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] element.
[In PasswordRecoveryEnabled] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [PasswordRecoveryEnabled] element.
[In Policies] The Policies element is a required container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element that specifies a collection of security policies.
[In Policies] It [Policies element] is a child of the Provision element (section 2.2.2.44).
[In Policies] The Policies element has only the following child element: Policy (section 2.2.2.41): At least one element of this type is required.
[In Policies] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Policies] element.
[In Policies] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Policies] element.
[In Policies] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Policies] element.
[In Policies] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Policies] element.
[In Policies] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Policies] element.
[In Policy] The Policy element is a required container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element that specifies a policy.
[In Policy] It [Policy element] is a child of the Policies element (section 2.2.2.40).
[In Policy] This element [Policy] is valid in both a command request and a command response.
[In Policy] In the initial Provision command request, the Policy element has the following child element: PolicyType (section 2.2.2.43) (required).

[In Policy] In the initial Provision command response, the Policy element has only the following child elements: PolicyType (section 2.2.2.43) (required) PolicyKey (section 2.2.2.42) (required) Status (section 2.2.2.54.1) (required) Data (section 2.2.2.24) ( required).

[In Policy] In the acknowledgment Provision command request, the Policy element has the following child elements: PolicyType (section 2.2.2.43) (required) PolicyKey (section 2.2.2.42) (required, MUST appear before the Status element) Status (section 2.2.2.54.1) (required).

[In Policy] In the acknowledgment Provision command response, the Policy element has the following child elements: PolicyType (section 2.2.2.43) (required) PolicyKey (section 2.2.2.42) (required) Status (section 2.2.2.54.1) (required).
[In Policy] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Policy] element.
[In Policy] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Policy] element.
[In Policy] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Policy] element.
[In Policy] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Policy] element.
[In Policy] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Policy] element.
[In PolicyKey] The PolicyKey element is an optional element of type string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7) with a maximum of 64 characters and no child elements.
[In PolicyKey] It [PolicyKey] is a child element of the Policy element (section 2.2.2.41).
[In PolicyKey] The value of the PolicyKey element SHOULD be a string representation of a 32-bit unsigned integer.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R711.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In PolicyKey] PolicyKey is used by the server to mark the state of policy settings on the client in the settings download phase of the Provision command.
[In PolicyKey] When the client issues an initial Provision command, the PolicyKey tag and X-MS-PolicyKey are not included in the HTTP header.
[In PolicyKey] In the acknowledgement phase, the PolicyKey element is used by the client and server to correlate acknowledgements to a particular policy setting.
[In PolicyKey] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [PolicyKey] element.
[In PolicyKey] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [PolicyKey] element.
[In PolicyKey] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [PolicyKey] element.
[In PolicyKey] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [PolicyKey] element.
[In PolicyKey] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [PolicyKey] element.
[In PolicyType] The PolicyType element is a child element of type string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7) of the Policy element (section 2.2.2.41).
[In PolicyType] [The PolicyType element], in the download policy settings phase, specifies the format in which the policy settings are to be provided to the client device.
[In PolicyType] The value of the PolicyType element MUST be one of the values specified in the following table. [MS-WAP-Provisioning-XML MS-EAS-Provisioning-WBXML]
[In PolicyType] Value MS-WAP-Provisioning-XML meaning The contents of the Data element are formatted according to the WAP Windows Mobile provisioning XML schema, as specified in section 2.2.2.24.2.

[In PolicyType] Value MS-EAS-Provisioning-WBXML meaning The contents of the Data element are formatted according to the Exchange ActiveSync provisioning WBXML schema, as specified in section 2.2.2.24.1.
[In PolicyType] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [PolicyType] element.
[In PolicyType] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [PolicyType] element.
[In PolicyType] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [PolicyType] element.
[In PolicyType] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [PolicyType] element.
[In PolicyType] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [PolicyType] element.
[In PolicyType] The value "MS-EAS-Provisioning-WBXML" is used with protocol versions 12.0, 12.1, 14.0, 14.1, 16.0 and 16.1.
[In Provision] The Provision element is a required container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element in a provisioning request and response that specifies the capabilities and permissions of a device.

[In Provision] The Provision element has the following child elements: settings:DeviceInformation (section 2.2.2.53) Status (section 2.2.2.54.2) Policies (section 2.2.2.40) RemoteWipe (section 2.2.2.45) AccountOnlyRemoteWipe (section 2.2.2.1).
[In Provision] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Provision] element.
[In Provision] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Provision] element.
[In Provision] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Provision] element.
[In Provision] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Provision] element.
[In Provision] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Provision] element.
[In RemoteWipe] The RemoteWipe element is an optional container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element.
[In RemoteWipe] [The RemoteWipe element] specifies either a remote wipe directive from the server or a client's confirmation of a server's remote wipe directive.
[In RemoteWipe] A server response MUST NOT include any child elements in the RemoteWipe element.
[In RemoteWipe] The RemoteWipe element is sent in a command request only in response to a remote wipe directive from the server.
[In RemoteWipe] The RemoteWipe element has the following child element in a client request: Status (section 2.2.2.54.3): One element of this type is required.
[In RemoteWipe] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RemoteWipe] element.
[In RemoteWipe] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RemoteWipe] element.
[In RemoteWipe] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RemoteWipe] element.
[In RemoteWipe] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RemoteWipe] element.
[In RemoteWipe] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RemoteWipe] element.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] The RequireDeviceEncryption element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] [The RequireDeviceEncryption element] specifies whether the client uses encryption.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] The RequireDeviceEncryption element cannot have child elements.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Valid values [0,1] for RequireDeviceEncryption are listed in the following table.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Value 0 means Encryption is not required.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Value 1 means Encryption is required.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RequireDeviceEncryption] element.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RequireDeviceEncryption] element.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RequireDeviceEncryption] element.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RequireDeviceEncryption] element.
[In RequireDeviceEncryption] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RequireDeviceEncryption] element.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] The RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] [The RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages element] specifies whether the client sends encrypted email messages.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] The RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages element cannot have child elements.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Valid values [0,1] for RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages are listed in the following table.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Value 0 means Encrypted email messages are not required.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Value 1 means Email messages are required to be encrypted.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RequireEncryptedSMIMEMessages] element.

[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] The RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm element is an optional child element of type integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] [The RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm element] specifies the algorithm used when encrypting S/MIME messages.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] The RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm element cannot have child elements.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Valid values [0,1,2,3,4] for RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm are listed in the following table.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Value 0 means TripleDES algorithm.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Value 1 means DES algorithm.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Value 2 means RC2128bit.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Value 3 means RC264bit.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Value 4 means RC240bit.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RequireEncryptionSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] The RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] [The RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming element] specifies whether the device requires manual synchronization when the device is roaming.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] The RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming element cannot have child elements.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Valid values [0,1] for RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming are listed in the following table.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Value 0 means Do not require manual sync; allow direct push when roaming.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Value 1 means Require manual sync when roaming.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] element.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] element.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] element.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] element.
[In RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RequireManualSyncWhenRoaming] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] The RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm element is an optional child element of type integer ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] [The RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm element] specifies the algorithm used when signing S/MIME messages.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] The RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm element cannot have child elements.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Valid values [0,1] for RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm are listed in the following table.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Value 0 means Use SHA1.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Value 1 means Use MD5.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEAlgorithm] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] The RequireSignedSMIMEMessages element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] [The RequireSignedSMIMEMessages element] specifies whether the client sends signed S/MIME messages.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] The RequireSignedSMIMEMessages element cannot have child elements.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Valid values [0,1] for RequireSignedSMIMEMessages are listed in the following table.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Value 0 means Signed S/MIME messages are not required.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Value 1 means Signed S/MIME messages are required.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RequireSignedSMIMEMessages] element.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] The RequireStorageCardEncryption element is an optional child element of type boolean ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1) of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] [The RequireStorageCardEncryption element] specifies whether the device encrypts content that is stored on the storage card.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] The RequireStorageCardEncryption element cannot have child elements.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Valid values [0,1] for RequireStorageCardEncryption are listed in the following table.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Value 0 means Encryption of the device storage card is not required.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Value 1 means Encryption of the device storage card is required.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] This element SHOULD be ignored if the client does not support storing data on removable storage.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [RequireStorageCardEncryption] element.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [RequireStorageCardEncryption] element.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [RequireStorageCardEncryption] element.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [RequireStorageCardEncryption] element.
[In RequireStorageCardEncryption] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [RequireStorageCardEncryption] element.

[In settings:DeviceInformation] The settings:DeviceInformation element is an optional container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element that is used for sending the client device's properties to the server in an initial Provision command request.
[In settings:DeviceInformation] It [settings:DeviceInformation element] is a child of the Provision element (section 2.2.2.44).
[In settings:DeviceInformation] The settings:DeviceInformation element is defined in the Settings XML namespace, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.45.

[In settings:DeviceInformation] When the Provision command is used to send the settings:DeviceInformation element, it sends the information about the client device to the server, as specified for the settings:DeviceInformation element under the Settings command in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.18.
[In settings:DeviceInformation] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [settings:DeviceInformation] element.
[In settings:DeviceInformation] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [settings:DeviceInformation] element.
[In settings:DeviceInformation] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [settings:DeviceInformation] element.

[In settings:DeviceInformation] When protocol version 14.1, 16.0 or 16.1 is used, the client MUST send the settings:DeviceInformation element with its contents when sending an initial Provision command request to the server but not on subsequent requests.

[In settings:DeviceInformation] The settings:DeviceInformation element MUST contain a settings:Set ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.167) child element, and the settings:Set element MUST at least contain a settings:Model ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.115) child element.
[In settings:DeviceInformation] When protocol version 14.0, 12.1, or 12.0 is used, the client MUST NOT send the settings:DeviceInformation element in any Provision command request.

[In settings:DeviceInformation] In these cases [When protocol version 14.1, 16.0 or 16.1 is used, the client sends the settings:DeviceInformation element with its contents when sending an initial Provision command request to the server but not on subsequent requests. The settings:DeviceInformation element contains a settings:Set ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.167) child element, and the settings:Set element at least contains a settings:Model ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.115) child element. When protocol version 14.0, 12.1, or 12.0 is used, the client will not send the settings:DeviceInformation element in any Provision command request.], the settings:DeviceInformation element can be used in a Settings command request, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 3.1.5.2.
[In Status] The Status element is a child element of the Policy element (section 2.2.2.41).
[In Status] The Status element is a child element of the Provision element (section 2.2.2.44).
[In Status] The Status element is a child element of the RemoteWipe element (section 2.2.2.45).
[In Status] The definition of this element [Status] differs according to the context in which it [Status element] is used.
[In Status] [The definition of this element [Status] differs according to the context in which it is used] For more details, see section 2.2.2.54.1, section 2.2.2.54.2, and section 2.2.2.54.3.
[In Status (Policy)] The Status element is a required child of the Policy element in command responses.
[In Status (Policy)] The Status element is an optional child of the Policy element in command requests.
[In Status (Policy)] In a command response, the value of this element [Status (Policy)] is an unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8).
[In Status (Policy)] The [Status (Policy)] value indicates the success or failure of a client's initial request to retrieve policy settings from the server.
[In Status (Policy)] The following table lists valid values [1,2,3,4,5] for the Status (Policy) element when it is the child of the Policy element in the response from the server to the client.
[In Status (Policy)] Value 1 means Success.
[In Status (Policy)] Value 2 means There is no policy for this client.
[In Status (Policy)] Value 3 means Unknown PolicyType value.
[In Status (Policy)] Value 4 means The policy data on the server is corrupted (possibly tampered with).
[In Status (Policy)] Value 5 means The client is acknowledging the wrong policy key.
[In Status (Policy)] In a command request, the value of this element [Status (Policy)] is a string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7).
[In Status (Policy)] The value [Status (Policy)] indicates the success or failure of the client to apply the policy settings retrieved from the server.
[In Status (Policy)] The following table lists valid values [1,2,3,4] for the Status (Policy) element when it is the child of the Policy element in the request from the client to the server.
[In Status (Policy)] Value 1 means Success.
[In Status (Policy)] Value 2 means Partial success (at least the PIN was enabled).
[In Status (Policy)] Value 3 means The client did not apply the policy at all.
[In Status (Policy)] Value 4 means The client claims to have been provisioned by a third party.
[In Status (Policy)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Status (Policy)] element.
[In Status (Policy)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Status (Policy)] element.
[In Status (Policy)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Status (Policy)] element.
[In Status (Policy)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Status (Policy)] element.
[In Status (Policy)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Status (Policy)] element.
[In Status (Provision)] The Status (Provision) element is a required child element of the Provision element in command responses.
[In Status (Provision)] The value of this element [Status (Provision)] is an unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8).
[In Status (Provision)] The value indicates the success or failure of the Provision command.
[In Status (Provision)] The following table lists valid values [1,2,3] for the Status (Provision) element when it is the child of the Provision element.
[In Status (Provision)] For details about status values common to all ActiveSync commands, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.
[In Status (Provision)] Value 1 means Success.
[In Status (Provision)] Value 2 means Protocol error.
[In Status (Provision)] Value 3 means General server error.
[In Status (Provision)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Status (Provision)] element.
[In Status (Provision)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Status (Provision)] element.
[In Status (Provision)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Status (Provision)] element.
[In Status (Provision)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Status (Provision)] element.
[In Status (Provision)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Status (Provision)] element.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] The Status element is a required child of the RemoteWipe or AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element in command requests.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] The value of this element [Status (RemoteWipe)] is an unsignedByte ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.8).
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] The [Status (RemoteWipe)] value indicates the success or failure of a remote wipe operation on the client.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] The following table lists valid values [1,2] for the Status (RemoteWipe) element when it is the child of the RemoteWipe or AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] Value 1 means The client remote wipe operation was successful.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] Value 2 means The remote wipe operation failed.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [Status (RemoteWipe)] element.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [Status (RemoteWipe)] element.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [Status (RemoteWipe)] element.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [Status (RemoteWipe)] element.
[In Status (RemoteWipe)] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [Status (RemoteWipe)] element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] The UnapprovedInROMApplicationList element is an optional container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] [The UnapprovedInROMApplicationList element] specifies a list of in-ROM applications that are not approved for execution.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] It [UnapprovedInROMApplicationList element] is a child of the EASProvisionDoc element (section 2.2.2.28).
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] Only applications that are preinstalled in ROM are affected by the entries in this element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] This element does not apply to applications that are installed in-memory.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] A command response has a maximum of one UnapprovedInROMApplicationList element per EASProvisionDoc element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] The UnapprovedInROMApplicationList element has only the following child element: ApplicationName (section 2.2.2.21): This element is optional.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] Protocol version 12.1 supports this [UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] Protocol version 14.0 supports this [UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] Protocol version 14.1 supports this [UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] Protocol version 16.0 supports this [UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] element.
[In UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] Protocol version 16.1 supports this [UnapprovedInROMApplicationList] element.
[In Simple Types] The following table summarizes the set of common XML schema simple type [EmptyVal, unsignedByteOrEmpty, unsignedIntOrEmpty] definitions defined by this specficiation [MS-ASPROV].
[In Simple Types] Simple type EmptyVal (section 2.2.3.1) [is] A type that cannot contain a value.
[In Simple Types] Simple type unsignedByteOrEmpty (section 2.2.3.2) [is] A type that can either be an xs:unsignedByte ([XMLSCHEMA2/2] section 3.3.24) or empty.
[In Simple Types] Simple type unsignedIntOrEmpty (section 2.2.3.3) [is] A type that can either be an xs:unsignedInt ([XMLSCHEMA2/2] section 3.3.22) or empty.

[In EmptyVal Simple Type] The EmptyVal simple type represents an empty value. <xs:simpleType name="EmptyVal"> <xs:restriction base="xs:string"> <xs:maxLength value="0"/> </xs:restriction> </xs:simpleType>

[In unsignedByteOrEmpty Simple Type] The unsignedByteOrEmpty simple type represents a value that can either be an [xs:unsignedByte type, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2] section 3.3.24, or] an empty value. <xs:simpleType name="unsignedByteOrEmpty"> <xs:union memberTypes="xs:unsignedByte EmptyVal"/> </xs:simpleType>

[In unsignedByteOrEmpty Simple Type] The unsignedByteOrEmpty simple type represents a value that can either be an xs:unsignedByte type, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2] section 3.3.24, [or an empty value]. <xs:simpleType name="unsignedByteOrEmpty"> <xs:union memberTypes="xs:unsignedByte EmptyVal"/> </xs:simpleType>

[In unsignedIntOrEmpty Simple Type] The unsignedIntOrEmpty simple type represents a value that can either be [an xs:unsignedInt type, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2] section 3.3.22, or] an empty value. <xs:simpleType name="unsignedIntOrEmpty"> <xs:union memberTypes="xs:unsignedInt EmptyVal"/> </xs:simpleType>

[In unsignedIntOrEmpty Simple Type] The unsignedIntOrEmpty simple type represents a value that can either be an xs:unsignedInt type, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2] section 3.3.22, [or an empty value]. <xs:simpleType name="unsignedIntOrEmpty"> <xs:union memberTypes="xs:unsignedInt EmptyVal"/> </xs:simpleType>
[In Abstract Data Model] This section [3.1.1] describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol [MS-ASPROV].
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.

[In Abstract Data Model] This document [MS-ASPROV] does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model [a conceptual model of possible data organization] as long as their [implementations'] external behavior is consistent with that described in this document [MS-ASPROV].
[In Abstract Data Model] The following figure shows the process for downloading policy settings.
[In Abstract Data Model] The following table lists the command sequence for downloading policy settings.
[In Abstract Data Model] In order 1, the client sends a Provision command request with the type of policy settings to be downloaded.
[In Abstract Data Model] In order 1, the server response contains the policy type, policy key, data, and status code.

[In Abstract Data Model] In order 2, the client acknowledges that it [client] received and applied the policy settings by sending another Provision command request with the policy type, policy key, and status code.
[In Abstract Data Model] In order 2, the server response contains the policy type, policy key, and status code to indicate that the server recorded the client's acknowledgement.

[In Provision Command] The Provision command enables client devices to send the server information about the device, to request from the server the security policy settings set by the server administrator, and to report on the status of a remote wipe or an account only remote wipe directive.

[In Provision Command] The provisioning process has two phases: an initial phase consisting of a Provision command request sent by the client followed by an initial server response, then an acknowledgment phase consisting of a Provision command request sent by the client with an acknowledgment of the initial server response, followed by another server response.
[In Provision Command] Clients SHOULD<1> begin the provisioning process in the following scenarios: When contacting the server for the first time.
[In Provision Command] [Clients SHOULD<1> begin the provisioning process in the following scenarios:] When the server's response to any command indicates that the client needs to re-provision.

[In Provision Command] [Clients SHOULD<1> begin the provisioning process in the following scenarios:] Whether the server specifies this condition [When the server's response to any command indicates that the client needs to re-provision.] by returning a value in the Status element or by returning an HTTP 4xx or 5xx response code depends on the protocol version.

[In Provision Command] [Clients SHOULD<1> begin the provisioning process in the following scenarios:] [When the server's response to any command indicates that the client needs to re-provision. Whether the server specifies this condition by returning a value in the Status element or by returning an HTTP 4xx or 5xx response code depends on the protocol version.] For details, see the table of status values in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.
[In Provision Command] [Clients SHOULD<1> begin the provisioning process in the following scenarios:] When the server's response to any command indicates that the client needs to do a remote wipe.

[In Provision Command] [Clients SHOULD<1> begin the provisioning process in the following scenarios:] Whether the server specifies this condition [When the server's response to any command indicates that the client needs to do a remote wipe.] by returning a value in the Status element or by returning an HTTP 4xx or 5xx response code depends on the protocol version.

[In Provision Command] [Clients SHOULD<1> begin the provisioning process in the following scenarios:] [When the server's response to any command indicates that the client needs to do a remote wipe. Whether the server specifies this condition by returning a value in the Status element or by returning an HTTP 4xx or 5xx response code depends on the protocol version.] For details, see the table of status values in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.
[In Provision Command] The format of the Provision command request and response differs based on the context in which it [the format of the Provision command request and response] is used.
[In Provision Command] The contexts for the Provision command are: The initial request, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.1.
[In Provision Command] [The contexts for the Provision command are:] Acknowledging security policy settings, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.2.1.

[In Provision Command] [The contexts for the Provision command are:] Acknowledging a remote wipe directive, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.2.2, or an account only remote wipe directive, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.2.3.

[In Provision Command] The current security policy settings on the client are represented by the current policy key, which is sent to the server in the X-MS-PolicyKey header ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.2.8) if the client is using a plain text query value, as specified in [MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.1.2, or the Policy key field of the base64 encoded query value ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.1.1) if the client is using a base64 encoded query value.

[In Provision Command] The policy key is sent to the server for all protocol command requests except the Autodiscover command ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.1), the Ping command ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.13), and the HTTP OPTIONS command ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.3).

[In Initial Request] The client sends an initial provisioning request either to retrieve the current security policy settings or in response to the server's remote wipe or account only remote wipe directive.
[In Initial Request] During the initial provisioning request, the current policy key MUST be reset to 0 (zero).

[In Initial Request] To request the current security policy settings from the server, the client sends the initial provisioning request in the following format. <Provision> <settings:DeviceInformation> ... </settings:DeviceInformation> <Policies> <Policy> <PolicyType>...</PolicyType> <Policy> </Policies> </Provision>
[In Initial Request] The inclusion of the settings:DeviceInformation element depends on the protocol version that is being used.

[In Initial Request] If the initial provisioning request is in response to receiving a status code from the server indicating that a remote wipe is requested, the initial provisioning request SHOULD consist of an empty Provision element (section 2.2.2.44).

[In Initial Request] If the server response contains a RemoteWipe (section 2.2.2.45) or an AccountOnlyRemoteWipe (section 2.2.2.1) element within the Provision element, the client SHOULD acknowledge the remote wipe, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.2.2, or account only remote wipe, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.2.3.
[In Initial Request] For a remote wipe, the client SHOULD then destroy all data on the device and restore it to factory default settings.
[In Initial Request] For an account only remote wipe, the client SHOULD then destroy all data that it has ever received from the server and erase any stored credentials used to access the server.

[In Initial Request] If the server response includes a Status element (section 2.2.2.54.2) within the Provision element that indicates success, and also contains a Policies element (section 2.2.2.40) within the Provision element, the client ensures that the security policy settings contained in the Policy element (section 2.2.2.41) are actually enforced, and acknowledges the security policy settings, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.2.1.
[In Initial Request] Any elements that the client ignores because the client does not support the associated feature SHOULD be considered enforced.
[In Initial Request] The value of the PolicyKey element (section 2.2.2.42) contained within this Policy element is a temporary policy key that is only valid for the acknowledgment request.

[In Initial Request] The client SHOULD ignore any Policy element that has its PolicyType child element (section 2.2.2.43) set to a value that is not supported by the protocol version that is specified in the MS-ASProtocolVersion header.

[In Enforcing Password Requirements] The following elements represent the password requirements specified by a security policy: AllowSimpleDevicePassword (section 2.2.2.12) AlphanumericDevicePasswordRequired (section 2.2.2.20) DevicePasswordEnabled (section 2.2.2.25) DevicePasswordExpiration (section 2.2.2.26) DevicePasswordHistory (section 2.2.2.27) MaxDevicePasswordFailedAttempts (section 2.2.2.32) MinDevicePasswordComplexCharacters (section 2.2.2.37) MinDevicePasswordLength (section 2.2.2.38) PasswordRecoveryEnabled (section 2.2.2.39).

[In Enforcing Password Requirements] The client uses the following rules to enforce password requirements. 1. If the DevicePasswordEnabled element is missing or set to 0, the client SHOULD ignore the other password requirement elements.

[In Enforcing Password Requirements] [The client uses the following rules to enforce password requirements.] 2. The client SHOULD configure the device on which the client application is installed to require a password that meets all of the password requirements.

[In Enforcing Password Requirements] If it [client] does not configure the device to require the password, it [device] MUST instead require a password that meets the requirements to access the client application and any data that the client has received from the server.

[In Enforcing RequireDeviceEncryption] If the RequireDeviceEncryption element (as specified in section 2.2.2.46) is present and set to 1, the client SHOULD configure the device on which the client application is installed to encrypt all local storage.
[In Enforcing RequireDeviceEncryption] If it [client] does not configure the device to encrypt all local storage, it [device] MUST encrypt all data that the client has received from the server.

[In Acknowledgment Request] The second phase of the provisioning process, the acknowledgment phase, is either an acknowledgment of security policy settings (section 3.1.5.1.2.1), or an acknowledgment of a remote wipe directive (section 3.1.5.1.2.2).

[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] During the security policy settings acknowledgment request, the current policy key MUST be set to the temporary policy key obtained from the server response to the initial request, as specified in section 3.1.5.1.1.

[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] Clients include a security policy settings acknowledgment in the Provision command request sent immediately following the server response to a server policy settings request.

[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] A security policy settings acknowledgment uses the following format. <Provision> <Policies> <Policy> <PolicyKey>...</PolicyKey> <Status>...</Status> <PolicyType>...</PolicyType> <Policy> </Policies> </Provision>
[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] The value of the PolicyKey element (section 2.2.2.42) MUST be set to the temporary policy key obtained from the server response to the initial request.
[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] The client sets the value of the Status element to indicate the result of enforcement of the security policy, as specified in section 2.2.2.54.1.

[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] If the server response includes a Status element (section 2.2.2.54.2) within the Provision element that indicates success, and also contains a Policies element (section 2.2.2.40) within the Provision element, the client checks for a Policy element (section 2.2.2.41) that has a PolicyType child element (section 2.2.2.43).
[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] The value of the PolicyKey element contained within this Policy element is a permanent policy key that is valid for subsequent command requests.
[In Acknowledging Security Policy Settings] Any Policy element that has a PolicyType child element with a value other than those specified in section 2.2.2.43 SHOULD be ignored.

[In Acknowledging a Remote Wipe Directive] Clients include a remote wipe acknowledgment in the Provision command request sent immediately following a Provision command response that includes a RemoteWipe element (section 2.2.2.45) within the Provision element in the XML body.
[In Acknowledging a Remote Wipe Directive] A remote wipe acknowledgment uses the following format. <Provision> <RemoteWipe> <Status>...</Status> </RemoteWipe> </Provision>
[In Acknowledging a Remote Wipe Directive] The client sets the value of the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.3) to indicate the result of the remote wipe.
[In Acknowledging a Remote Wipe Directive] The client SHOULD then destroy all data contained on the device, returning it to original factory settings.

[In Acknowledging a Remote Wipe Directive] If it [client] does not destroy all data contained on the device, the client MUST destroy all data that it [client] has ever received from the server and erase any stored credentials used to access the server.
[In Acknowledging a Remote Wipe Directive] The client SHOULD NOT wait for or rely on any specific response from the server before proceeding with the remote wipe.

[In Acknowledging an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive] Clients include an account only remote wipe acknowledgment in the Provision command request sent immediately following a Provision command response that includes an AccountOnlyRemoteWipe element (section 2.2.2.1) within the Provision element in the XML body.

[In Acknowledging an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive] An account only remote wipe acknowledgment uses the following format. <Provision> <AccountOnlyRemoteWipe> <Status>...</Status> </AccountOnlyRemoteWipe> </Provision>
[In Acknowledging an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive] The client sets the value of the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.3) to acknowledge the account only remote wipe directive.
[In Acknowledging an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive] The client SHOULD then destroy all data that it has ever received from the server and erase any stored credentials used to access the server.
[In Acknowledging an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive] The client SHOULD NOT wait for or rely on any specific response from the server before proceeding with the remote wipe.
[In Provision Command Errors] The following table specifies the actions a client SHOULD take based upon the value of the Status element that is a child of the Provision element.
[In Provision Command Errors] Status codes greater than 100 are not supported by all protocol versions.
[In Provision Command Errors] For more details, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 1 [is] Success.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 1 is] The Policies element contains information about security policies.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 1 is] Apply the applicable policy.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 2 [is] Protocol error.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 2 is] Syntax error in the Provision command request.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 2 is ] Fix syntax in the request and resubmit.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 3 [is] An error occurred on the server.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 3 is] Server misconfiguration, temporary system issue, or bad item.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 3 is] This [An error occurred on the server.] is frequently a transient condition.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 3 is] Retry.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 139 [is] The client cannot fully comply with all requirements of the policy.

[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 139 is] The client returned a value of 2 in the Status child element of the Policy element in a request to the server to acknowledge a policy.<2>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R1046.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 139 is] The server is configured to not allow clients that cannot fully apply the policy.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 139 is] Server administrator intervention is required.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 141 [is] The device is not provisionable.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 141 is] The client did not submit a policy key value in a request.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 141 is] The server is configured to not allow clients that do not submit a policy key value.

[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 141 is] Include a policy key value in the X-MS-PolicyKey header ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.2.8) or the Policy key field of the Base64 Encoded Query Value ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.1.1).
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 145 [is] The client is externally managed.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 145 is] The client returned a value of 4 in the Status child element of the Policy element in a request to the server to acknowledge a policy.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 145 is] The server is configured to not allow externally managed clients.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 145 is] The client can issue a new Provision request and apply the policy, overwriting any external provisioning.

[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 145 is] If this [The client can issue a new Provision request and apply the policy, overwriting any external provisioning.] is not possible, server administrator intervention is required.
[In Provision Command Errors] The following table specifies the actions a client SHOULD take based upon the value of the Status element that is a child of the Policy element.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 1 [is] Success.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 1 is] The requested policy data is included in the response.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 1 is] Apply the policy.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 2 [is] Policy not defined.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 2 is] No policy of the requested type is defined on the server.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 2 is] Stop sending policy information.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 2 is] No policy is implemented.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 3 [is] The policy type is unknown.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 3 is] The client sent a policy that the server does not recognize.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 3 is] Issue a request with the PolicyType element set as specified in section 2.2.2.43.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 4 [is] Policy data is corrupt.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 4 is] The policy data on the server is corrupt.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 4 is] Server administrator intervention is required.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The meaning of status value] 5 [is] Policy key mismatch.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 5 is] The client is trying to acknowledge an out-of-date [or invalid policy].
[In Provision Command Errors] [The cause of status value 5 is] The client is trying to acknowledge an [out-of-date or] invalid policy.
[In Provision Command Errors] [The resolution of status value 5 is] Issue a new Provision request to obtain a valid policy key.
[In Abstract Data Model] This section [3.2.1] describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol [MS-ASPROV].
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.

[In Abstract Data Model] This document [MS-ASPROV] does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model [a conceptual model of possible data organization] as long as their external behavior is consistent with that described in this document [MS-ASPROV].
[In Abstract Data Model] See section 3.1.1 for more details.

[In Provision Command] The Provision command enables servers to obtain device information from client devices, to send security policy settings set by the server administrator and set a shared policy key, and to send a remote wipe or an account only remote wipe directive.

[In Provision Command] The server SHOULD require that the client device has requested and acknowledged the security policy settings before the client is allowed to synchronize with the server, unless a security policy is set on the server to allow it [client is allowed to synchronize with the server].
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R509.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Provision Command] The server relies on the client to apply the security policy settings on the client device.

[In Provision Command] The Provision command has two phases: an initial phase consisting of a client request followed by an initial server response, then an acknowledgment phase consisting of a client request with an acknowledgment of the initial server response, followed by another server response.
[In Provision Command] The format of the Provision command request and response differs based on the context in which it [the format of the Provision command request and response] is used.
[In Provision Command] The contexts for the Provision command are: The initial request, as specified in section 3.2.5.1.1.
[In Provision Command] [The contexts for the Provision command are:] Acknowledging security policy settings, as specified in section 3.2.5.1.2.1.

[In Provision Command] [The contexts for the Provision command are:] Â§ Acknowledging a remote wipe directive, as specified in section 3.2.5.1.2.2, or account only remote wipe directive, as specified in section 3.2.5.1.2.3.
[In Provision Command] The server generates, stores, and sends the policy key when it responds to a Provision command request for policy settings.
[In Provision Command] The current policy key on the client represents the current security policy settings.

[In Provision Command] The current policy key is received from the client for all protocol command requests except for the Autodiscovercommand ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.1), the Ping command ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.1.13), and the HTTP OPTIONS command ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.3).

[In Provision Command] The current policy key SHOULD be received from the client in the X-MS-PolicyKey header ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.2.8) if the client is using a plain text query value, as specified in [MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.1.2, or the Policy key field of the base64 encoded query value ([MS-ASHTTP] section 2.2.1.1.1.1) if the client is using a base64 encoded query value.

[In Provision Command] If the policy key received from the client does not match the stored policy key on the server [, or if the server determines that policy settings need to be updated on the client], the server SHOULD return a status code, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2, in the next command response indicating that the client needs to send another Provision command to request the security policy settings and obtain a new policy key.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R537.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Provision Command] If [the policy key received from the client does not match the stored policy key on the server , or if ]the server determines that policy settings need to be updated on the client, the server SHOULD return a status code, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2, in the next command response indicating that the client needs to send another Provision command to request the security policy settings and obtain a new policy key.
[In Responding to an Initial Request] The server SHOULD store the device information that was specified in the settings:DeviceInformation element (section 2.2.2.53) sent by the client device .

[In Responding to an Initial Request] [The server] SHOULD respond to an initial security policy settings Provision command request with a response in the following format. <Provision> <settings:DeviceInformation> <settings:Status>...</settings:Status> </settings:DeviceInformation> <Status>...</Status> <Policies> <Policy> <PolicyType>...</PolicyType> <Status>...</Status> <PolicyKey>...</PolicyKey> <Data> ... </Data> </Policy> </Policies> </Provision>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R535.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to an Initial Request] The contents of the PolicyType element (section 2.2.2.43) and the Data element (section 2.2.2.24) depend on the protocol version that is being used.
[In Responding to an Initial Request] The settings:DeviceInformation element is not supported by some protocol versions.
[In Responding to an Initial Request] For details about these elements and protocol versions, see the element definitions.

[In Responding to an Initial Request] The value of the PolicyKey element (section 2.2.2.42) is a temporary policy key that will be valid only for an acknowledgment request to acknowledge the policy settings contained in the Data element.

[In Responding to an Initial Request] When a policy setting that was previously set is unset on the server, the server SHOULD specify the element that represents the setting as an empty tag or a default value.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R1042, MS-ASPROV_R1045.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to an Initial Request] In these cases, the client SHOULD either unset these values if they were previously set or leave the setting unchanged.

[In Responding to an Initial Request] The server SHOULD respond to an empty initial Provision command request with a response in the following format. <Provision> <Status>...</Status> <RemoteWipe/> </Provision>
or <Provision> <Status>â€¦</Status> <AccountOnlyRemoteWipe/> </Provision>
or
<Provision> <Status>â€¦</Status> </Provision>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R758.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to an Initial Request] The RemoteWipe or AccountOnlyRemoteWipe MUST only be included if a remote wipe or an account only remote wipe has been requested for the client.
[In Responding to an Initial Request] Otherwise [if a remote wipe has not been requested for the client], it [RemoteWipe] MUST be omitted

[In Responding to an Acknowledgment Request] The second phase of the provisioning process, the acknowledgment phase, is either an acknowledgment of security policy settings (section 3.2.5.1.2.1), or an acknowledgment of a remote wipe directive (section 3.2.5.1.2.2).

[In Responding to a Security Policy Settings Acknowledgment] The server MUST ensure that the current policy key sent by the client in a security policy settings acknowledgment matches the temporary policy key issued by the server in the response to the initial request from this client.

[In Responding to a Security Policy Settings Acknowledgment] If it does not [current policy key sent by the client in a security policy settings acknowledgment does not match the temporary policy key issued by the server in the response to the initial request from this client], the server SHOULD return a Status (section 2.2.2.54.2) value of 5, as specified in section 3.2.5.2.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R695.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to a Security Policy Settings Acknowledgment] If the policy key matches the temporary policy key, the server SHOULD check the value of the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.1) sent by the client in the acknowledgment to determine the client's reported level of compliance with the security policy.

[In Responding to a Security Policy Settings Acknowledgment] If the level of compliance does not meet the server's requirements, the server SHOULD return an appropriate value in the Status (section 2.2.2.54.2) element.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R697.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to a Security Policy Settings Acknowledgment] If the level of compliance meets the server's requirements, the server response is in the following format. <Provision> <Status>...</Status> <Policies> <Policy> <PolicyType>...</PolicyType> <Status>...</Status> <PolicyKey>...</PolicyKey> </Policy> </Policies> </Provision>

[In Responding to a Security Policy Settings Acknowledgment] The value of the PolicyKey element (section 2.2.2.42) is a permanent policy key that is valid for subsequent command requests from the client.

[In Responding to a Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgment] The server SHOULD record the status of the remote wipe reported by the client in the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.3) of the acknowledgment request.
[In Responding to a Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgment] If the client reports success, the server SHOULD return a value of 1 in the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.2).<3>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R1041, MS-ASPROV_R1047.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to a Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgment] If the client reports failure, the server SHOULD return a value of 2 in the Status element [and a remote wipe directive]<4>.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R1042, MS-ASPROV_R1048.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to a Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgment] If the client reports failure, the server SHOULD return [a value of 2 in the Status element and] a remote wipe directive.<4>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Verified by derived requirement: MS-ASPROV_R702.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Responding to a Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgment] The server's response is in the following format. <Provision> <Status>...</Status> <RemoteWipe/> </Provision>

[In Responding to an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgement] The server SHOULD record the status of the account only remote wipe reported by the client in the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.3) of the acknowledgment request.
[In Responding to an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgement] If the client reports success, the server SHOULD return a value of 1 in the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.2).

[In Responding to an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgement] If the client reports failure, the server SHOULD return a value of 2 in the Status element[ and an account only remote wipe directive].

[In Responding to an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgement] If the client reports failure, the server SHOULD return [a value of 2 in the Status element and ]an account only remote wipe directive.
[In Responding to an Account Only Remote Wipe Directive Acknowledgement] The server's response is in the following format. <Provision> <Status>...</Status> <AccountOnlyRemoteWipe/> </Provision>
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is] Policy, [the meaning of status value] 1 [is] Success.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the cause of status value 1 is] The requested policy data is included in the response.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the resolution of status value 1 is] Apply the policy.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is] Global, [the meaning of status value] 2 [is] Protocol error.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Global], [the cause of status value 2 is] Syntax error in the Provision command request.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Global], [the resolution of status value 2 is] Fix bug in client code.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is] Policy, [the meaning of status value] 2 [is] Policy not defined.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the cause of status value 2 is] No policy of the requested type is defined on the server.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the resolution of status value 2 is] Stop sending policy information.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the resolution of status value 2 is] [Stop sending policy information. ] No policy is implemented.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is] Policy, [the meaning of status value] 3 [is] The policy type is unknown.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the cause of status value 3 is] The client sent a policy that the server does not recognize.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the resolution of status value 3 is] Issue a request with the PolicyType element set as specified in section 2.2.2.43..
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is] Global, [the meaning of status value] 3 [is] An error occurred on the server.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Global], [the cause of status value 3 is] Server misconfiguration, temporary system issue, or bad item.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Global], [the cause of status value 3 is] This [An error occurred on the server.] is frequently a transient condition.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Global], [the resolution of status value 3 is] Retry.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is] Policy, [the meaning of status value] 5 [is] Policy key mismatch.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the cause of status value 5 is] The client is trying to acknowledge an out-of-date or invalid policy.
[In Provision Command Errors] [When the scope is Policy], [the resolution of status value 5 is] Issue a new Provision request to obtain a valid policy key.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Unless otherwise specified, any statement of optional behavior in this specification that is prescribed using the terms SHOULD or SHOULD NOT implies product behavior in accordance with the SHOULD or SHOULD NOT prescription.
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Unless otherwise specified, the term MAY implies that the product does not follow the prescription.
[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] The value of the PolicyKey element is a string representation of a 32-bit unsigned integer. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] The implementation does require that the client device has requested and acknowledged the security policy settings before the client is allowed to synchronize with the server, unless a security policy is set on the implementation to allow it [client is allowed to synchronize with the implementation]. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] The implementation does respond to a security policy settings request in an initial Provision command request with a response in the following format. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.) <Provision> <settings:DeviceInformation> <settings:Status>...</settings:Status> </settings:DeviceInformation> <Status>...</Status> <Policies> <Policy> <PolicyType>MS-EAS-Provisioning-WBXML</PolicyType> <Status>...</Status> <PolicyKey>...</PolicyKey> <Data> <EASProvisionDoc> ... </EASProvisionDoc> </Data> </Policy> </Policies> </Provision>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If it does not [current policy key sent by the client in a security policy settings acknowledgment does not match the temporary policy key issued by the server in the response to the initial request from this client], the implementation does return a Status (section 2.2.2.53.2) value of 5, as specified in section 3.2.5.2. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the level of compliance does not meet the server's requirements, the implementation does return an appropriate value in the Status (section 2.2.2.53.2) element. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the client reports failure, the implementation does return [a value of 2 in the Status element and] a remote wipe directive. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] When a policy setting that was previously set is unset on the server, the implementation does specify the element that represents the setting as an empty tag [or a default value]. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] When a policy setting that was previously set is unset on the server, the implementation does specify the element that represents the setting as [an empty tag or] a default value. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] The implementation does respond to an empty initial Provision command request with a response in the following format. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.) <Provision> <Status>...</Status> <RemoteWipe/> </Provision>
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] <1> Section 3.1.5.1: Windows 8.1 does not send a Provision command when contacting the server for the first time.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] [The cause of status value 139 is] The client returned a value of 2 in the Status child element of the Policy element in a request to the implementation to acknowledge a policy. (<2> Section 3.1.5.2: In Microsoft Exchange Server 2007 and Exchange 2010, this does not cause status code 139.)

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] [The cause of status value 139 is] The client returned a value of 2 in the Status child element of the Policy element in a request to the implementation to acknowledge a policy. (Exchange 2013 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the client reports success, the implementation does return a value of 1 in the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.2). (<3> Section 3.2.5.1.2.2: In Exchange 2007 and Exchange 2010, if the client reports success, the server returns a value of 1 in the Status element and a remote wipe directive.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the client reports success, the implementation does return a value of 1 in the Status element (section 2.2.2.54.2). (Exchange 2013 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the client reports failure, the implementation does return a value of 2 in the Status element [and a remote wipe directive]. (<4> Section 3.2.5.1.2.2: In Exchange 2007 and Exchange 2010, if the client reports failure, the server returns a value of 1 in the Status element.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the client reports failure, the implementation does return a value of 2 in the Status element [and a remote wipe directive]. (Exchange 2013 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In Appendix B: Product Behavior] If the policy key received from the client does not match the stored policy key on the server [, or if the server determines that policy settings need to be updated on the client], the implementation does return a status code, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.4, in the next command response indicating that the client needs to send another Provision command to request the security policy settings and obtain a new policy key. (Exchange 2007 and above follow this behavior.)
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: This requirement can be enabled/disabled in the deployment.ptfconfig file.

[In boolean Data Type] It [a boolean] is declared as an element with a type attribute of "boolean".
[In boolean Data Type] The value of a boolean element is an integer whose only valid values are 1 (TRUE) or 0 (FALSE).
[In boolean Data Type] Elements with a boolean data type MUST be encoded and transmitted as [WBXML1.2] inline strings.
[In container Data Type] A container is an XML element that encloses other elements but has no value of its own.
[In container Data Type] It [container] is a complex type with complex content, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA1/2] section 3.4.2.
[In integer Data Type] Elements with an integer data type MUST be encoded and transmitted as WBXML inline strings, as specified in [WBXML1.2].
[In string Data Type] A string is a chunk of Unicode text.
[In string Data Type] An element of this [string] type is declared as an element with a type attribute of "string".
[In string Data Type] Elements with a string data type MUST be encoded and transmitted as [WBXML1.2] inline strings.
[In string Data Type] Elements of these types [ActiveSync defines several conventions for strings that adhere to commonly used formats]are defined as string types in XML schemas.
[In unsignedByte Data Type] The unsignedByte data type is an integer value between 0 and 255, inclusive.
[In unsignedByte Data Type] Elements of this type [unsignedByte type] are declared with an element whose type attribute is set to "unsignedByte".
